qas.question: What is MPI an abbreviation for?
How many classes of chronic pain patients are there?
What do dysfunctional people perceive the severity of their pain to be?
What do interpersonally distressed people feel their significant others aren't supportive of?
What should MPI characterization of a person be combined with for deriving the most useful case descriptions?

plausible_answers.text: a questionnaire designed to assess the psychosocial state of a person with chronic pain

qas.question: How many classes of chronic pain patient did Turk and Rudy find in 1898?

plausible_answers.text: people who perceived the severity of their pain to be high, reported that pain interfered with much of their lives

qas.question: What is the definition of a dysfunctional pain patient according to the 1898 results of Turk and Rudy?

plausible_answers.text: patients who reported high levels of social support, relatively low levels of pain and perceived interference, and relatively high levels of activity

qas.question: What is the definition of adaptive copers according to the 1898 results by Turk and Rudy?

context: The <a0_0><b6_0>Multidimensional Pain Inventory<b6_0/><a0_0/> (MPI) is <b5_0>a questionnaire designed to assess the psychosocial state of a person with chronic pain<b5_0/>. Analysis of MPI results by Turk and Rudy (1988) found <a1_0><b7_0>three<b7_0/><a1_0/> classes of chronic pain patient: "(a) dysfunctional, <b8_0>people who perceived the severity of their pain to be <a2_0>high<a2_0/>, reported that pain interfered with much of their lives<b8_0/>, reported a higher degree of psychological distress caused by pain, and reported low levels of activity; (b) interpersonally distressed, people with a common perception that significant others were not very supportive of <a3_0>their pain problems<a3_0/>; and (c) adaptive copers, <b9_0>patients who reported high levels of social support, relatively low levels of pain and perceived interference, and relatively high levels of activity<b9_0/>." Combining the MPI characterization of the person with <a4_0>their IASP five-category pain profile<a4_0/> is recommended for deriving the most useful case description.
